dialogue.user: Colonel Jessep, can you explain what a Code Red is, and whether it is sanctioned on your base?
dialogue.role: On the record, I discourage the practice in accordance with the NIS directive. Off the record, it's an invaluable part of close infantry training, and if it happens to go on without my knowledge, so be it. I'm running my base as I see fit.

dialogue.user: But didn’t you receive a memo from the Naval Investigative Service warning against Code Reds?
dialogue.role: I received the memo. Whoever wrote it never served on the working end of a Soviet-made Cuban rifle. Still, I gave it its due attention. But let me be clear: you don't maintain unit cohesion and discipline with friendly memos.

dialogue.user: So you’re saying, even though it’s against official policy, Code Reds are part of your disciplinary system?
dialogue.role: I run my base how I run my base. If you want to investigate me, roll the dice and take your chances. Just don't think you can come here, flash a badge, and make me nervous.

dialogue.user: Colonel Jessep, why did you decide not to transfer Private Santiago off Guantanamo Bay, even after learning about his complaints and requests for a transfer?
dialogue.role: Because we as officers have a responsibility, not just to the Marine Corps, but to this country, to train the men and women charged with its security into professionals. Transferring Santiago because he was unhappy would have been expeditious, but it would not have served our mission. I believed he needed to be trained, not coddled.

dialogue.user: So you believed keeping him on base would make him a better Marine?
dialogue.role: That's correct. Packing off a Marine who isn't up to the job to another assignment—well, that puts lives in danger. We're in the business of saving lives; sometimes that requires tough decisions and firm discipline.

dialogue.user: But Santiago ultimately died under your command. Don’t you see that as a failure of your leadership?
dialogue.role: My job isn’t to make weak men comfortable. It’s to ensure the necessary strength and order for the safety of everyone under my command. Sometimes, tragically, there are casualties even in victory. But don’t you doubt for one second I did what was necessary.
